claim: If increased airflow speed is applied during lithium plating, then the detectability of knee pathways with electrochemically undetectable signals is improved, because increased airflow speed enhances the mass transport of reactants and products, leading to a more pronounced signal of internal state trajectories, which in turn allows for better detection of knee pathways.

mechanism.effect: Enhanced mass transport of reactants and products

mechanism.cause: Enhanced mass transport of reactants and products
mechanism.effect: More pronounced signal of internal state trajectories

mechanism.cause: More pronounced signal of internal state trajectories
mechanism.effect: Improved detectability of knee pathways with electrochemically undetectable signals

prediction: We expect to observe an increase in Li inventory reversibility of knee pathways with electrochemically undetectable signals
null_result: If we observe no significant change in Li inventory reversibility, the hypothesis is rejected
gap_addressed: Paper 2208.12902v1 shows that the proposed formulation exhibits low sensitivity to numerical parameters, but Paper 2201.02891v1 mentions that some knee pathways have internal state trajectories with signals that are electrochemically undetectable, which may indicate a contradiction in the sensitivity of numerical parameters to detect knee pathways
experiments: Apply varying airflow speeds (0.0 m/s to 15.0 m/s) during lithium plating and measure the Li inventory reversibility of knee pathways with electrochemically undetectable signals

claim: If anisotropic representation in phase-field simulations of electrodeposition is used to optimize the integration of phase change materials (PCMs) in lithium-ion battery packs, then the thermal performance of the battery packs is improved, because the anisotropic representation allows for more accurate modeling of lithium dendrite growth rates and morphologies, which in turn enables the optimization of PCM placement and design

mechanism.effect: More accurate modeling of lithium dendrite growth rates and morphologies

mechanism.cause: More accurate modeling of lithium dendrite growth rates and morphologies
mechanism.effect: Optimization of PCM placement and design

mechanism.cause: Optimization of PCM placement and design
mechanism.effect: Improved thermal performance of lithium-ion battery packs

prediction: We expect to observe a reduction in the temperature variation of the battery pack by 15-25% compared to a baseline without anisotropic representation and PCM optimization
null_result: If we observe no significant reduction in temperature variation or if the results are within the margin of error of the baseline, the hypothesis is rejected
gap_addressed: The integration of phase change materials (PCMs) in lithium-ion battery packs has been studied, and the use of anisotropic representation in phase-field simulations of electrodeposition has been explored, but no study combines these concepts to analyze thermal performance of lithium-ion battery packs with anisotropic electrodeposition
experiments: Design and simulate a lithium-ion battery pack with anisotropic representation in phase-field simulations of electrodeposition and optimized PCM placement, and compare the thermal performance to a baseline without anisotropic representation and PCM optimization

claim: If solid-ion conductors (SICs) with high shear modulus are used in lithium-ion batteries, then the formation of the knee in aging trajectories is postponed, because SICs suppress dendrite formation and alleviate pressure-driven instabilities, which in turn reduce mechanical deformation and electrode saturation, leading to delayed knee formation.

mechanism.effect: Reduction of mechanical deformation and electrode saturation

mechanism.cause: Reduction of mechanical deformation and electrode saturation

prediction: We expect to observe a decrease in the rate of capacity fade leading up to the knee point, indicating a postponement of knee formation.
null_result: If we observe no significant change in the rate of capacity fade leading up to the knee point, the hypothesis is rejected.
gap_addressed: The concept of knee modeling in lithium-ion battery aging trajectories has been explored, and the use of solid-ion conductors (SICs) to suppress dendrite formation has been studied, but no study combines these concepts to analyze the effect of SICs on knee formation in lithium-ion batteries
experiments: Cycle lithium-ion battery cells with and without high shear modulus SICs under controlled airflow speeds (0.0 m/s and 15.0 m/s) and measure capacity retention over time.
